captions.text:
I'm here to rip apart
your assumptions about money.
I'm going to show you

that behind the financial crisis
and the environmental crisis,

lies a hidden crisis,
in our monetary system,
the very way our money is created.
And I'm also going to show you

that there is this community of people
growing around the world

that are using the latest technologies
to create new currencies
that will serve us and not the banks.

And I'm going to call for media,
old and new,
to tell this new stories of money.
Although we use money everyday

often many of us don't really know
the first thing about it

in terms of how is created
and how that affects us.

So what I would like to do
is a little thought experiment with you.

I'd like you to imagine
that you are living in a village

way back in time,
let's say 3,000 years ago.

Some of you bake bread,
some of you look after chickens,

some of you fix clothes,
so you all swap stuff amongst yourselves.
It's a barter economy.

Then one day,
a knight comes to your village,

and he looks at what you're doing
and says: "Why don't you use my tokens?

It will be so much easier for you,
you can swap them."

So you decide to give it a go,
and he lends each of you ten tokens.

So you start using this
and you find it's great!

You no longer have to swap
your bread for eggs.

You don't have to remember
who owes who what,
you can just swap the tokens.

So you find suddenly
you have a lot more free time.
It's great for you.
You ask the knight to keep the tokens
and he agrees on one condition:

that at the end of the year,
when he returns,
he can see that you've got 11 tokens;

otherwise, you will forfeit
your assets to him.

Now, because they become
so useful to you,
you agree and you'll try this out.

Time goes by and everything is fine,
but then you realize he's returning soon,
so you start to ask more for your bread,

you start to ask more
to fix people's clothes,

and you realize that your neighbors
have done the same thing.

So suddenly there is a lot less tokens
circulating in your village.
The knight returns,

and not everyone has 11 tokens,
it's impossible.

[Therefore], some of you
lose your homes, lose your farms.
In this situation,
might this technology of tokens meant

that you changed the way
you relate, and what you value,
and how you even feel?
Do you think in this situation

you might come to see
the tokens as the wealth,

and not yourself, your neighbors,
your village or you environment?
Fast forward 3,000 years

and our money system
today is quite like that,
just now is on cocaine!

Literally, if some reports
are to be believed.
(Laughter)
Now, this is not to be joked about,

it is so important
to whatever you are working on,
we have to really address these issues.
I've worked for 16 years

helping large companies,
UN agencies and charities
team up to address global challenges,

like climate change, overfishing,
forced labor, HIV/AIDS,
and we've created some cool correlations

that are changing
business practices worldwide.
But some of us have come to realize

that if we want to change business
in really widespread and lasting ways,

if we want to change the way
business does business,

we must now change the way
money makes money.

Unfortunately, there aren't many people
funding work in this area
(Laughter)
as I found out.

To work on it more,
I had to outsource myself to India,

where I ended up working with an NGO
called Community Forge

and they create
free open source software

for communities
to run their own currencies.

Through working with them,
I had my eyes open

to this whole world of innovation
and complementary currencies,

where some of them are using
units of hours work,

some of them are even looking
at using "kilowatt hours,"
some pegged to a national currency.
And I also realized

that advances in social networks
and mobile payment systems
means we are on the verge of a revolution

in the scale and uptaking use
of such currencies.

Soon you will be up to walk
into your local store,

ask for the bill in a local currency
and pay with you mobile phone

through an SMS
or near field communication.

Just yesterday in Brixton, in London,
they launched just such a scheme.

I will return later
to this issue of innovation,

but one of the most important things
I understand
from beginning to work on this,
is that I realize I, like many people,

have so many
completely unfounded assumptions
about what money is.

Someone asked me
the simplest of questions:
"Where does money come from?"
"Where does money come from?"

I am a Professor of Management,
not Economics,
but I like to think I know things,

and it's a very simple question,
and I didn't have a clue.

I offered the idea that:
"Wow, doesn't Government create it?"
Then I found out that yes,

3% of all money is created
by governments in the mint,

so these are the coins
and the notes we have.

But the rest, in nearly
all countries of the world,
the remaining 97%,

is made by banks,
private banks, it's electronic.
They create this with interest, of course.
So when you go to a bank,

did you think that the bank had the money
to lend you, when you borrow it?

I did. But no, they create it
out of nothing.

And of course, as I say,
they create it with interest.

But they don't create the interest,
so who creates the interest?

It's created with another loan,
with more interest.

So it means today, in the world,
there is more debt than money.
Just like with the knight and his tokens,

we can't pay off the debts,
there is just not enough money.

Individually we might, but collectively,
we are in debt forever.
We are paying compound interest forever.
This creates a lot of problems,
but for time, I'll mention just two.

The first is this system of money creation
as debt, with interest,
means that increasing economic inequality,
--differences between rich and poor--
is a mathematical certainty.

No wonder then
the 2% of people in the world

now controls half, or more than half
of the world's wealth.
The second problem is environmental.

Because we need more and more landing
to catch up because of all the interest,

we must have more and more products
and services traded,

and therefore we must have
more consumption of natural resources,
otherwise the system will collapse,

and we'll have to fell through cession,
and so on.

We don't have
and exponentially expanding planet,
as far as I'm aware,

and so, this money system means
that, for all our ingenuity,

all we are doing
is delaying the ultimate crash

that has been pre-programmed
by this stupid money system.
So that's the theory.

But how does this really feel?
Who's got some money?
I've brought along 20 euros.

Let me see your money. Show me
your money, I want to see some money.
We know this is just paper, don't we?
We know this is paper.

As paper is not that useful to us,
we can scribble on it maybe,

or write a prayer and put it
under your pillow and pray.
But it's just, just paper.

We choose to make it worth something
more that that because that's help for us,

but it would be a delusion
to think it has value in itself.
It's just paper, it's just money.
We are the wealth, us.

Our ability and our desire
to do things for each other.

It would be a delusion
to think this is wealth.

And If we run our society
as if this is wealth,
haven't we gone completely mad?

You turn on the telly,
as I think many of you do,
and what do to see?

You see everyone talking about growth,
we need more growth to restore growth.

I used to think anyone
talking like this was a nutter,
and maybe you can relate to that now.
(Laughter)

I think it was my desire to be relevant
and my fear of being ridiculed

that helped me back from working
on these critical issues.

I've realized that the mass media,
many of you guys,

help to define what's considered
relevant or ridiculous.

You have a key responsibility
to encourage effective debate

about the real causes
of all these crises we are seeing.
I looked on-line for a quick check
and I found that about 42 million webpages
mention financial crisis.

So guess how many of those
also mention monetary reform?

Just over a hundred and so thousand,
so about 0.3%;
it's almost as if there is a taboo

about talking about the real causes
for our current problems.
What if media embraced this responsibility

to challenge our assumptions,
to dig a bit deeper,

and what if journalists
asked our top politicians

the simplest of questions:
"Where does money come from?"

You might get some funny answers.
It might make for some amusing TV.

Fortunately, we do have
the weld of new media
--as we've been hearing about--

and this is allowing independent voices
to reach audiences of millions worldwide.
So home-made films like "Money is debt"

have been watched
over a million times on YouTube.
Social networks mean

that currency innovators
and campaigners for monetary reform

can share what they're doing
and learn from each other.

There is one initiative
I'm engaged in, called:

The Finance Innovation Lab,
in the UK, and through that,

we are learning about all these
different initiatives and innovations.
Clearly, we need to work out

how to deal with this problem of banks
creating money from nothing at interest.

But I'm not holding my breath
on that one,

that we're going to see
much leadership on that,

what I'm doing is engaging with people
who are creating new currencies.

I've realized that there are now
hundreds of thousands of people worldwide,

from slums of Rio and Nairobi
to business hubs in Bristol and Brussels,

people creating and using
their own currencies.

If you are interested,
you can look online, for say:
TimeBanks in the US, Lets in the UK,

Regiogeld in Germany,
The WIR in Switzerland.
You can look UP Bitcoin,

an entirely digital currency
that has become huge in just a year.

You can look
at collaborative consumption websites

which help neighbors share staff,
--not such a new idea.

Then we're looking at creating currencies
so people don't have to pay,

You have other ways,
of just swapping things,

and you don't have to have money
in order to be helpful to your community.

But all this innovations mean
we need a clearer idea

about what kind of currencies
would be good for us, not harmless.

So, it doesn't mean going back
to scarce metal as our money,

it doesn't mean waiting for Facebook
to create the new global private currency,
as I'm sure they will one day.

We need to be clear about
what kind of money is going to serve us
and I think that must be money

that is issued as a public utility
and it's not issued for private profit.

The current money system,
as I've described,
has been ripping apart our planet

and is now even tearing apart
our communities.

Maybe, when you looked
at the news in the last week,
it's even ripping itself to pieces.
But it doesn't have to be that way.

There are people now that I'm working with
who are creating currencies

that weave together communities,
not tear them apart.
So we don't need to kneel to the banks.

We can stand for
what we really value in each other

and we can start by losing
our delusions about money,

working for real reform,
trying real alternatives,

and telling a whole new story
about money,
and ourselves.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: The Money Myth: Jem Bendell at TEDxTransmedia2011

comments.text:
There is no evidence that societies in history that only used the barter 
system without a medium of exchange (money, credit ...), see 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barter. And it's probably because it's so 
inefficient. For example, if I only have clay pots but want fish. But the 
person who has the fish, he wants bread. Then I have to find someone who 
has bread ...

But agree that our current debt system is not so good. However, while it 
may not be completely bad. For example, Japan has a massive public debt of 
over 200% of GDP. But the majority is indigenous and in their own currency. 
So the state can create new money to pay off the debt and also collect 
money through taxes.

Personally I do not think local currencies like the Brixton pound is the 
right way. Not that it would not work, but it would be far too complicated 
to eg collect taxes, exchange currencies for multinational companies and 
tourists ...

I think Debt Jubilee is an interesting idea. In biblical Israel where debts 
forgiven every 50 years or so. Not that it would be a complete solution. 
Then it also applies to not spend more than you have and have bad debt.﻿
comments.author: mikael klintred (zinou81)

comments.text:
I agree we need to demand more from our money itself. We need smarter 
money. The fossil fuel currencies €/¥/$ are not reflecting the additional 
value we expect them to represent, e.g. environmental impact, social 
impact, corruption impact, impact of wars, inegality, etc. are not very 
well represented/captured.  There's a solution if we have identified what 
are the key issues that have a potential of bringing humanity to its knees. 
We just have to quantify and agree upon a fair burden sharing per 
country/human. With CO2e certificates were doing it to a large extend. If 
you'd see a fossil fuel power plant as a printing machine/generator of 
€/¥/$, since the Emission Trading System, the fossile plant cannot print 
those anymore UNLESS they deposit every year the equivalent amount of CO2e 
certificates = money of the green economy that can only be generated if 
someone has taken out the fair burden quantity of CO2e out of the 
atmosphere, hence solving the global climate destabilization.  Among 
academics, there's about 15 other of such challenges that are generally 
agreed upon that can bring humanity to its knees. We now need a similar ETS 
and 15 currencies for those as well and you can only print your €/$/¥ 
unless you deposit every year/quarter the fair quantity you took upon you / 
has been imposed.  You can either do that yourself: bring e.g. 10.000 kids 
to the point they have their primary education degree, or you can pay a 
team to do that for you.  That's how you bring ressources to the right 
people who do know how to solve these apparently life threatening 
challenges.  More: google MyAgenda21.﻿
comments.author: Sven AERTS

comments.text:
I don't see where the fuss is. Cf. Fractional banking: a bank that has 10€ 
in cash, can actually write out a loan for 100€... that's just an economy 
where participants have a lot of trust in their economy, i.e. that there 
will be no "run on the banks" any time short, and that 10€ invested will 
allow to generate indeed 90€ in additional value.  Some of the additional 
value will be created by the entrepreneurial team, but some will also be 
created by third parties who all of a sudden realize the initial 
entrepreneurs haven't thought of some opportunities that become possible 
thanks to their innovation, maybe because of time constraints, etc. If 
there would be a run on the bank, I assume it will be foreseable and the 
financial sector will gradually start making loans more expensive as 
something very worrying seems to be causing this and the mint will start 
minting more coins and notes, because it has been agreed that additional 
value is expressed in euro's, etc. if you have them in an electronic or 
physical form is up to the one who generated that additional value, i.e. 
the one who owns the euro's.  I don't see why the central mint wouldn't 
give the people their coins if they prefer that.  There's disadvantages in 
having cash coins at home iso on a screen/computer that's well guarded by 
the bank/financial system.  ﻿
comments.author: Sven AERTS

I don't see where the fuss is.  So, a couple of companies come together and 
contact a bank to borrow them money to co-finance a project and the project 
goes bust. Then the bank my own the buildings, mobilia, etc. but if it 
can't sell it at a good price, it takes all the loss too.  Banks who have 
that happen too often, go bankrupt too. There is a stick behind the door.﻿

comments.text:
I'm not impressed by the article you referred to.  
"
Here's something interesting: 
The Bailout Scorecard - Last update: Apr. 20, 2015

Altogether, accounting for both the TARP and the Fannie and Freddie 
bailout, $615B has gone out the door—invested, loaned, or paid out—while 
$390B has been returned.

The Treasury has been earning a return on most of the money invested or 
loaned. So far, it has earned $280B. When those revenues are taken into 
account, the government has realized a $55.1B profit as of Apr. 20, 2015.

More: https://projects.propublica.org/bailout/

ProPublica was a recipient of the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in National Reporting 
and a 2010 Pulitzer Prize in Investigative Reporting.
"

comments.text:
1.I don't think I'm an apologist. I think schools and media should educate 
more about the economic system, how money is created, the different types 
of money, what quality parameters to check when choosing a bank/an 
insurance company/..., etc.  Over generalisations and creating an 
atmosphere as if everything would be bad, that our democracy has no power 
or specialists at all, or that there are no regulations, is not educative 
and is dangerous because it turns people away from democracy and towards 
extremism.
2. usurious = http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usury#Usury_law = protection 
from "usury=excessively high interest rates and unfavourable conditions". 
Can't you ask your network to add some lines on how things are regulated in 
Europe? It only has regulations from the USA, Canada and Japan.
3. People are too optimistic and too readily take up loans without taking 
precautions e.g. what in case one becomes unemployed.  This seems to be 
relevant: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usury#Non-recourse_mortgages
3. I've asked for help on expanding the wikipedia usury article.  Maybe 
your network can help: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Finance#The_.22usury.22_article_needs_help_putting_links_to_other_articles
4. I have to go. Will continue reading later. But thx for the replies. Keep 
them coming.

comments.text:
Hi V. Can you re-edit your first phrase. I can't understand it.  What is 
QE? Anyway, cf. the houses of the people, this is what my answer would be. 
 Where does the money come from for the houses? You're worried about some 
ever growing and faster growing bubble, right?  It is true, banks can write 
out loans. But only if they are liable to these loans. They take on a huge 
risk/responsability, they balance by the knowledge of the local economy, 
they know the people to whom they give the loan, their financial situation, 
etc.   These people loaners HAVE to be working in a company generating so 
much additional value, so they can pay a salary and guarantee a long term 
contract.  If not, and they loose their job, and they cannot pay the loan, 
the bank is in a big problem too. And if there is a bubble created because 
of a bad remuneration system in the banking world, the bubble will in the 
end explode and the "market" will correct itself if people nearby won't 
find the discipline to correct themselves.
comments.author: Sven AERTS

comments.author: Verónica L. Lian Maseras

comments.text:
+Verónica L. Lian Maseras Hi V, thanks for the answer & question.  I can 
answer that: The interest is paid with part of the total amount of money 
that gets "printed for real or digitally" by the national bank, equivalent 
to the additional value created by whatever it is that the team/people 
asked a loan for.  I assume they had a great idea and proposed to the 
bank/venture capitalists etc;  "Hey, borrow / invest money in us so we can 
buy that machine so we can make this wonderful thing that saves everybody 
time and that's why people will buy the products we can make with it".  The 
idea even convinced the bank and the venture capitalists to get on board - 
both who balance the risk with their knowledge and reserve funds.  And if 
it works out, customers will indeed go to their banks, get money from their 
bank accounts, and exchange it for the products made with the help of the 
machine.  If at the bank of these customers, the reserve for cash money 
fall under a threshold, the bank manager will file a document to the 
national bank to ask to print more money. The next day, you read in the 
newspaper: the economy has grown by so many millions of €/$/¥.  Let me know 
if you can poke a hole in my understanding of the financial system.

comments.author: Furry “Albion” Monster

comments.text:
I like the good intention of his thinking and some of the alternatives 
(esp. Bitcoins) are VERY useful, I think. So on the one hand he IS getting 
everybody on the right track! On the other hand, these "revelations" about 
the nature of money also tend to misrepresent its role in our capitalist 
economy. That's very unfortunate, because the opportunity to follow this 
through and see the big picture is a good one:

For example, you cannot really say that it's precisely "interest" which 
forces the economy to grow exponentially. That's because you cannot 
separate the monetary system with its specific value-form (->interest) from 
a complete analysis of capitalism. The "root of the evil" is already 
contained in the way we humans perceive the general nature of commodities: 
Profit, rent, interest... all represent the same thing in a different 
disguise! 
So interest isn't some kind of evil scheme that Jewish bankers have 
invented to screw us (a common line of thought known as "structural 
antisemitism"), but just one of the many ways in which surplus value makes 
its appearance.

Another way to illustrate this would be to point out that there's no way 
for capital to reproduce itself in a global economy without some form of 
credit (which by the way is the deeper reason behind the eternal cycles of 
debt accumulation, crisis and monetary reform). 

Conclusion: If you are against profit seeking(->exploitation) then you 
should question capitalism as a whole. 19th century workers who witnessed 
the transition to industrialized wage labor understood this perfectly on an 
intuitive level. It was the great ideological achievement of 20th century 
consumer society to brainwash this nasty little insight from our collective 
mind. 

I invite you to put down your preconceptions and go read the first chapter 
of Marx's "Kapital". It is incredibly deep and dense. But if you can follow 
him there, then you'll have some true revelations, far greater than any TED 
video could ever give you!﻿

comments.text:
Why would he say it's not possible to have 11 tokens by the end of the 
year? 1 Year N token isn't necessarily the same as 1 Year N+1 token, and if 
the ration is 1:1.1 then it's possible for everyone to have 11 Year N 
tokens by Year N+1. Whether or not the fictional characters in this story 
make that mistake is irrelevant. The fact of the matter is that those 
semantics, when properly fleshed out, yield an opposite answer to his 
thought experiment.﻿

comments.author: Guillaume Paquet

comments.text:
So long as people wish to live beyond their means, there's always going to 
be interest, banks or no banks, fiat currency or not. So long as there's 
interest, people are going to have to do more work to pay back the interest 
than the things they wanted to buy with the loan. This is unavoidable. 
Whether a bank creates that money our of thin air or not is not a problem 
either, what's a problem is when they've let out so many loans that they 
don't have even a fraction of the assets to back up those loans, and a 
recession hits.

The real problem lies in people thinking it is fine for a bank to put a 
loan on their balance sheet as both an asset AND a liability, rather than 
having separate categories of assets and liabilities where the two 
categories cannot be simply "cancelled out" against each other. A loan 
might be considered a long term asset, but the moment someone defaults on 
the loan, that long term asset goes to zero and the short term liability 
stays. What happens when an institution like this is leveraged 20 to 1 and 
a recession hits in which 5% of the loans go into default? That bank's 
value drops to zero, that's what.

However, if you simply put in a regulation that limits banking leverage, 
they'll just find other clever accounting tricks to get around it and keep 
doing what they're doing. There is simply no alternative to being vigilant 
and examining what's going on. If you as a saver refuse to deal with a bank 
which does anything other than protect savings and make loans to people of 
good credit, and reject any which take on more than 2 to 1 leverage, that 
would be a step in the right direction.

If you really want to figure out where all the money is going, multiply the 
average hourly wage in your country by the size of the workforce and 
compare it against the size of the annual budget of your government. You 
will see that a large portion of your money is being consumed by 
governments, and what do you get for it? Lousy services and a bunch of debt 
in your name. THAT is where most of it is going.﻿

comments.text:
Yes you are right, however the problem occurs when the borrower deposits 
the $90 lent by the bank. From this $81 can be lent out, then $72.90 (90% 
of $81) and so on based on a 10% fractional reserve rate. That initial $100 
deposit in effect can ultimately behave like approximately $1000 through 
this multiplicative effect while the multiple banks (or one single bank) 
involved are collecting interest at every stage.

no that is not how it works. if they dont have 10k they cant let you borrow

comments.author: Crazylalalalala

comments.text:
They don't 'make' money, they 'create it'. Go to the bank and borrow 10K 
(choose your currency). They add 10K to your account, they don't take it 
out of a vault. The total money supply has now increased by 10K. Forgetting 
interest for a moment let's say you pay back the 10k in a couple of weeks. 
This means that the balance is back to zero and the general money supply 
has now dropped by 10K (putting it back where it was). Any plus balance 
means a corresponding debt somewhere else in the system.
